text: United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit
label: HH2

text: ROBERT INGRUM,
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff-Appellant,
label: BODY

text: UNITED STATES,
label: BODY

text: Defendant-Appellee.
label: BODY

text: Ryan G. Anderson, McClenahan Anderson & Stryker, P.L.L.C., of San Antonio,
label: BODY

text: Texas, argued for plaintiff-appellant.
label: BODY

text: Robert P. Stockman, Trial Attorney, Appellate Section, Environment and Natural
label: BODY

text: Resources Division, United States Department of Justice, of Washington, DC, argued for
label: BODY

text: defendant-appellee.  On the brief were Ronald J. Tenpas, Assistant Attorney General,
label: BODY

text: Kathryn C. Kovacs and Robert H. Oakley, Attorneys.
label: BODY

text: Appealed from:  United States Court of Federal Claims
label: BODY

text: Judge Mary Ellen Coster Williams
label: BODY

text: United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit
label: HH2

text: ROBERT INGRUM,
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff-Appellant,
label: BODY

text: UNITED STATES,
label: BODY

text: Defendant-Appellee.
label: BODY

text: Appeal from the United States Court of Federal Claims
label: BODY

text: in 07-CV-012, Judge Mary Ellen Coster Williams.
label: BODY

text: DECIDED:  March 25, 2009
label: BODY

text: Before RADER, BRYSON, and MOORE, Circuit Judges.
label: BODY

text: BRYSON, Circuit Judge.
label: BODY

text: Robert Ingrum filed an action seeking just compensation for the government’s
label: BODY

text: removal of fill material from a hillside on his property.  The Court of Federal Claims
label: BODY

text: dismissed the action as time-barred under the applicable six-year statute of limitations.
label: BODY

text: We affirm.
label: BODY

text: On March 16, 1999, Mr. Ingrum purchased approximately 3,300 acres of
label: BODY

text: undeveloped land along the Mexican border near the small town of Candelaria, Texas.
label: BODY

text: He paid $98,000 for the property.  An unpaved road, known as “the River Road,”
label: BODY

text: provides the only vehicular access to the property.  The paved highway that connects
label: BODY

text: with the River Road ends in Candelaria, about four miles from the edge of Mr. Ingrum’s
label: BODY

text: property.  The River Road crosses his property for about 2.75 miles and then continues
label: BODY

text: northward along the Rio Grande.  The property can be accessed by road from both the
label: BODY

text: north and the south, although access from the north involves traversing a much longer
label: BODY

text: stretch of unimproved road.
label: BODY

text: In 1997, heavy rainfall eroded a portion of the River Road south of the property.
label: BODY

text: A task force from the Department of Defense built a bypass around the washed-out
label: BODY

text: stretch of road and made additional improvements to the road.  Those repairs were
label: BODY

text: completed in 1998, prior to Mr. Ingrum’s purchase of the property.  To perform those
label: BODY

text: repairs, the task force used fill material that it had excavated, with the permission of the
label: BODY

text: previous landowner, from the side of a hill near a gravel pit on the property.  Rainfall
label: BODY

text: during the summer of 1998 again washed out portions of the road, including some of the
label: BODY

text: roadwork that was completed earlier that year.  The task force therefore returned to
label: BODY

text: perform additional repairs.  Before the government performed those repairs, Mr. Ingrum
label: BODY

text: signed a “Right of Entry” permit authorizing the government to enter the property to
label: BODY

text: repair the road and to carry out military training and other operations on the land.  Mr.
label: BODY

text: Ingrum signed that permit on March 13, 1999, shortly before closing on the property.
label: BODY

text: The Right of Entry permit also contained a provision that stated: “The Owner (does/does
label: BODY

text: not) grant the Government the right to use any buildings, timber or any other products of
label: BODY

text: the land.”  Mr. Ingrum did not select either the “does” or “does not” option when
label: BODY

text: executing the permit; instead, that portion of the form was left blank.
label: BODY

text: From March through April 1999, the government repaired the road by regrading it
label: BODY

text: in some places, installing concrete culverts, and laying concrete slabs in flood-prone
label: BODY

text: areas.  To conduct those repairs, the government again excavated fill material from the
label: BODY

text: same hillside borrow pit on Mr. Ingrum’s property.  The removal of the fill material left a
label: BODY

text: “bowl-like formation” on the hillside that was plainly visible from the portion of the River
label: BODY

text: Road that crossed the property.  Mr. Ingrum estimated that the excavated area was
label: BODY

text: roughly 200 feet across.
label: BODY

text: Prior to purchasing the property, Mr. Ingrum had accessed it from the south on
label: BODY

text: numerous occasions.  Approaching from that direction, the trip to the property was a 12-
label: BODY

text: hour drive from Mr. Ingrum’s residence in Austin, Texas.  Although Mr. Ingrum
label: BODY

text: attempted to make that drive several times after the government completed its repairs of
label: BODY

text: the road in April 1999, he was unable to drive onto the property on those occasions
label: BODY

text: because flooding had rendered portions of the River Road south of the property
label: BODY

text: impassable.  Mr. Ingrum was aware that the River Road was passable from the north,
label: BODY

text: but he chose not to access his property from that direction because doing so “would
label: BODY

text: have required an additional 7-9 hours of driving” along rough, unpaved roads, which he
label: BODY

text: regarded as “an untenable option.”
label: BODY

text: Several times between 1999 and 2004, Mr. Ingrum spoke by telephone with a
label: BODY

text: Border Patrol agent in order to determine the condition of the River Road; the agent
label: BODY

text: reported on several occasions that the road was passable from the south.  Mr. Ingrum
label: BODY

text: did not attempt to access his property on those occasions, however, because those
label: BODY

text: were all times when it was not convenient for him to make the drive.
label: BODY

text: Because Mr. Ingrum did not visit his property between April 1999 and 2005, he
label: BODY

text: did not learn about the hillside borrow pit until he happened to encounter a migrant
label: BODY

text: worker in Candelaria in May 2004.  The worker, who had crossed Mr. Ingrum’s property
label: BODY

text: in order to gain access to the Rio Grande, told Mr. Ingrum about the pit and commented
label: BODY

text: that the government construction workers “took a lot of material” from the hillside.
label: BODY

text: Some eight or nine months later, Mr. Ingrum visited his property and saw the borrow pit
label: BODY

text: for the first time.
label: BODY

text: On August 2, 2006, another 18 months after seeing the borrow pit, Mr. Ingrum
label: BODY

text: filed a takings claim against the United States in the Court of Federal Claims.  He
label: BODY

text: sought $324,000 in compensation for the taking of the fill material that was used for the
label: BODY

text: 1999 road repairs.  Although that figure was more than three times the price that Mr.
label: BODY

text: Ingrum had paid for the entire 3300-acre property in 1999, Mr. Ingrum justified the
label: BODY

text: amount as an estimate of what it would have cost the government to purchase and
label: BODY

text: transport from the nearest gravel pit enough material to rebuild seven miles of road.
label: BODY

text: After dismissing his suit voluntarily to cure an unrelated jurisdictional defect, Mr. Ingrum
label: BODY

text: filed another complaint in the Court of Federal Claims on January 9, 2007.
label: BODY

text: The government sought dismissal of the action as time-barred under the six-year
label: BODY

text: statute of limitations for actions falling within the jurisdiction of the Court of Federal
label: BODY

text: Claims.  Mr. Ingrum argued that his claim did not accrue at the time the fill material was
label: BODY

text: taken in March and April 1999, because he was unaware of the taking and had no
label: BODY

text: reason to be aware of it until he learned about the borrow pit in May 2004.  He
label: BODY

text: contended that he was not chargeable with knowledge of the taking because he lived
label: BODY

text: far from the property, he had been unable to access the property from the south on
label: BODY

text: several occasions because of poor road conditions, and the Right of Entry permit had
label: BODY

text: not given him notice that the government intended to take material from his land.  For
label: BODY

text: those reasons, he argued that his takings claim accrued only when he first learned of
label: BODY

text: the alleged taking in 2004.  Accordingly, he contended that his suit, which was filed in
label: BODY

text: 2006, was filed within the six-year limitations period.
label: BODY

text: The Court of Federal Claims ruled that because the actions giving rise to the
label: BODY

text: takings claim were not inherently unknowable, Mr. Ingrum’s claim accrued in April 1999
label: BODY

text: when the government completed its repair work.  Ingrum v. United States, 81 Fed. Cl.
label: BODY

text: 661 (2008).  Accordingly, the court dismissed Mr. Ingrum’s action as time-barred under
label: BODY

text: the applicable statute of limitations.  Mr. Ingrum now appeals to this court.
label: BODY

text: A claim falling within the jurisdiction of the Court of Federal Claims must be
label: BODY

text: brought within six years of the date that the cause of action accrued.  28 U.S.C. § 2501.
label: BODY

text: A claim first accrues when all the events have occurred that fix the alleged liability of the
label: BODY

text: government and entitle the claimant to institute an action.  Therefore, a claim alleging a
label: BODY

text: Fifth Amendment taking accrues when the act that constitutes the taking occurs.
label: BODY

text: Alliance of Descendants of Tex. Land Grants v. United States, 37 F.3d 1478, 1481
label: BODY

text: (Fed. Cir. 1994).
label: BODY

text: The parties in this case agree that the alleged taking occurred no later than April
label: BODY

text: 1999, when the government task force removed the fill material from the hillside on Mr.
label: BODY

text: Ingrum’s property.  That accrual date would place Mr. Ingrum’s suit, which he first filed
label: BODY

text: on August 2, 2006, outside the six-year limitations period.  Mr. Ingrum therefore seeks
label: BODY

text: the benefit of the “accrual suspension” rule.  Under that rule, the accrual of a claim
label: BODY

text: against the United States will in some situations be suspended when an accrual date
label: BODY

text: has been ascertained, but the plaintiff does not know of the claim.  Japanese War Notes
label: BODY

text: Claimants Ass’n v. United States, 373 F.2d 356, 358-59 (Ct. Cl. 1967).  However, a
label: BODY

text: plaintiff’s ignorance of a claim that he should have been aware of is not enough to
label: BODY

text: suspend the accrual of a claim.  Id. at 359; see Braude v. United States, 218 Ct. Cl.
label: BODY

text: 270, 274 (1978).  The accrual suspension rule is “strictly and narrowly applied,” and the
label: BODY

text: accrual date of a cause of action will be suspended in only two circumstances: “[the
label: BODY

text: plaintiff] must either show that defendant has concealed its acts with the result that
label: BODY

text: plaintiff was unaware of their existence or it must show that its injury was ‘inherently
label: BODY

text: unknowable’” at the time the cause of action accrued.  Martinez v. United States, 333
label: BODY

text: F.3d 1295, 1319 (Fed. Cir. 2003) (en banc), quoting Welcker v. United States, 752 F.2d
label: BODY

text: 1577, 1580 (Fed. Cir. 1985); Alliance of Descendants of Tex. Land Grants, 37 F.3d at
label: BODY

text: 1482; Catawba Indian Tribe v. United States, 982 F.2d 1564, 1571-72 (Fed. Cir. 1993);
label: BODY

text: Japanese War Notes Claimants Ass’n, 373 F.2d at 359.1
label: BODY

text: Mr. Ingrum does not contend that the government concealed its actions.  His sole
label: BODY

text: argument is that his action is not time-barred because the alleged taking was inherently
label: BODY

text: unknowable as of the accrual date.  We conclude that the facts underlying Mr. Ingrum’s
label: BODY

text: 1     It is sometimes stated that accrual of a claim against the United States will be
label: BODY

text: suspended until the claimant “knew or should have known” that the claim existed.  See
label: BODY

text: Kinsey v. United States, 852 F.2d 556, 557 n.* (Fed. Cir. 1988).  That articulation of the
label: BODY

text: rule is not meant to set forth a different test, as the two standards have been used
label: BODY

text: interchangeably.  See Young v. United States, 529 F.3d 1380, 1384 (Fed. Cir. 2008);
label: BODY

text: Hopland Band of Pomo Indians v. United States, 855 F.2d 1573, 1577 (Fed. Cir. 1988).
label: BODY

text: However, the “concealed or inherently unknowable” formulation, which the trial court
label: BODY

text: used in this case, is both more common and more precise, and we therefore continue to
label: BODY

text: endorse that formulation as the preferable one for “accrual suspension” cases.  See
label: BODY

text: Martinez v. United States, 333 F.3d at 1319.
label: BODY

text: claim were not inherently unknowable because the government’s excavation of the fill
label: BODY

text: material was an open and notorious activity conducted on his property, and because Mr.
label: BODY

text: Ingrum was on notice of the government’s repair activities and of the possibility that the
label: BODY

text: government would use fill from his property in the course of those activities.
label: BODY

text: The line of “accrual suspension” cases dealing with takings claims has
label: BODY

text: established that “[w]here the actions of the government are open and notorious . . . [the]
label: BODY

text: plaintiff is on inquiry as to its possible injury,” and the statute of limitations begins to run.
label: BODY

text: Coastal Petroleum Co. v. United States, 228 Ct. Cl. 864, 867 (1981).  In Coastal
label: BODY

text: Petroleum, the plaintiff sought just compensation more than six years after the
label: BODY

text: government used, and prevented access to, the plaintiff’s limestone in order to construct
label: BODY

text: a canal in Florida.  Because the canal project was widely reported in the state news
label: BODY

text: media, and because the plaintiff had admitted that it was aware of the project, the court
label: BODY

text: concluded that the government’s actions were open and notorious and that the plaintiff
label: BODY

text: was therefore “on inquiry as to the threat to its property rights.”  Id.
label: BODY

text: The Court of Federal Claims applied the same principle in Catellus Development
label: BODY

text: Corp. v. United States, 31 Fed. Cl. 399 (1994), in which a landowner brought a takings
label: BODY

text: claim against the government for mistakenly shelling his remote property during artillery
label: BODY

text: exercises and allegedly contaminating his land with unexploded ordnance.  The court
label: BODY

text: concluded that the bombing exercises were open and notorious acts that placed the
label: BODY

text: landowner on inquiry that it had a possible claim, thus triggering the limitations period.
label: BODY

text: Id. at 408 n.8; see also Voisin v. United States, 80 Fed. Cl. 164, 176 (2008)
label: BODY

text: (construction of houses on disputed property was “clearly an open and notorious
label: BODY

text: activity” putting plaintiffs on notice of the government’s actions); Jakoby v. United
label: BODY

text: States, 38 Fed. Cl. 192, 195 (1997) (absence of roadway or passage to plaintiff’s
label: BODY

text: property was “open and notorious” condition precluding tolling of limitations period);
label: BODY

text: LaFont v. United States, 17 Cl. Ct. 837, 842 (1989) (government dredging operation that
label: BODY

text: allegedly damaged plaintiff’s oyster beds was “an obvious act” that set the accrual date
label: BODY

text: for plaintiff’s takings claim); cf. Dahl v. United States, 319 F.3d 1226, 1229 (10th Cir.
label: BODY

text: 2003) (accrual of Federal Tort Claims Act claim not suspended under “discovery rule”
label: BODY

text: because destruction of 30-foot high stockpile of mineral ore was a “manifest injury” that
label: BODY

text: would have been obvious upon inspection).2
label: BODY

text: These authorities stand for the principle, which we reaffirm, that a landowner will
label: BODY

text: be deemed to be on inquiry of activities that are openly conducted on his property.
label: BODY

text: Applying that principle to this case, it is apparent that the government’s use of the fill
label: BODY

text: material from Mr. Ingrum’s property was an open and notorious act that put him on
label: BODY

text: inquiry that he had a potential claim.  By Mr. Ingrum’s own estimation, the borrow pit
label: BODY

text: created by the government’s use of the fill material had a footprint of roughly 35,000
label: BODY

text: square feet.  Mr. Ingrum concedes that if he had visited his property after the
label: BODY

text: government performed the 1999 repairs, he would have discovered the pit because it
label: BODY

text: was “in plain sight” and clearly visible from the road.  Under those circumstances, the
label: BODY

text: government’s actions cannot fairly be described as inherently unknowable.
label: BODY

text: 2     The concept of an “open and notorious” condition has been applied most
label: BODY

text: frequently in the law of adverse possession, where it plays a similar role.  See William
label: BODY

text: B. Stoebuck & Dale A. Whitman, The Law of Property 856 (2000) (“‘Open and notorious’
label: BODY

text: possession usually means possession that gives visible evidence to one on the surface
label: BODY

text: of the possessed land.  The purpose of this element is to afford the owner opportunity
label: BODY

text: for notice.  He need not actually have seen the evidence, but is charged with seeing
label: BODY

text: what reasonable inspection would disclose.”).
label: BODY

text: Furthermore, like the plaintiff in Coastal Petroleum, Mr. Ingrum was aware of the
label: BODY

text: construction on his property.  Indeed, Mr. Ingrum signed the Right of Entry permit
label: BODY

text: explicitly authorizing the government task force to enter his property in order to
label: BODY

text: reconstruct portions of the River Road on and near that property.  Because Mr. Ingrum
label: BODY

text: knew of the construction activities, he was on inquiry that he had a potential takings
label: BODY

text: claim.  See Coastal Petroleum, 228 Ct. Cl. at 867; see also Fallini v. United States, 56
label: BODY

text: F.3d 1378, 1380 (Fed. Cir. 1995) (“[A] plaintiff does not have to possess actual
label: BODY

text: knowledge of all the relevant facts in order for a cause of action to accrue.”).
label: BODY

text: Mr. Ingrum argues that although the Right of Entry permit provided notice of the
label: BODY

text: government’s construction activities on his land, it did not give him any reason to
label: BODY

text: suspect that the government would use fill material from his property in the course of
label: BODY

text: those activities.  In support of that contention, Mr. Ingrum relies on the fact that the
label: BODY

text: Right of Entry permit included a provision that would have expressly authorized the
label: BODY

text: government to use “buildings, timber or any other products of the land,” yet he did not
label: BODY

text: indicate on the permit whether he “does” or “does not” so authorize the government.
label: BODY

text: Thus, Mr. Ingrum argues, it was reasonable for him to assume that the government
label: BODY

text: would not take any material from his property.
label: BODY

text: In fact, the provision in the Right of Entry permit addressing the government’s
label: BODY

text: authorization to use products from the land cuts the other way:  Its very presence put
label: BODY

text: Mr. Ingrum on notice that the government contemplated that the repairs would
label: BODY

text: necessitate the use of material from Mr. Ingrum’s property, regardless of whether he
label: BODY

text: affirmatively granted that permission.  The question whether Mr. Ingrum granted the
label: BODY

text: government permission to use material from his property goes to the merits of his
label: BODY

text: takings claim; it does not negate the fact that the authorization provision put Mr. Ingrum
label: BODY

text: on notice that the government might need to use fill material from the property.
label: BODY

text: Although Mr. Ingrum could not be sure that the government would do so (and may have
label: BODY

text: hoped that it would not), he clearly knew enough at the time the government completed
label: BODY

text: its repairs to make an inquiry and discover the facts underlying his takings claim.  See
label: BODY

text: Menominee Tribe of Indians v. United States, 726 F.2d 718, 721 (Fed. Cir. 1984).
label: BODY

text: Having failed to make such an inquiry, Mr. Ingrum cannot now avail himself of the
label: BODY

text: accrual suspension rule.
label: BODY

text: Finally, Mr. Ingrum argues that it would be unreasonable to expect him to have
label: BODY

text: discovered the government’s alleged taking any earlier.  He notes that his property is
label: BODY

text: located several hundred miles from his residence in Austin; that he tried to access his
label: BODY

text: property via the southern route several times, but was thwarted by poor road conditions;
label: BODY

text: that the occasions on which he knew that the River Road was passable from the south
label: BODY

text: were all times that were inconvenient for him to visit; and that it would have taken an
label: BODY

text: additional 7-9 hours of driving on rough terrain to access his property from the north.
label: BODY

text: We are not persuaded that those circumstances satisfy the strict standard of showing
label: BODY

text: that the government’s action was “inherently unknowable.”  As discussed above, a
label: BODY

text: landowner is on inquiry as to open and notorious activities conducted on his property.
label: BODY

text: That principle applies regardless of how far the landowner resides from the disputed
label: BODY

text: property.  Thus, it is immaterial whether Mr. Ingrum lived in Austin or New York City, as
label: BODY

text: opposed to some closer location such as Candelaria, or that it would have taken him
label: BODY

text: longer to access his property via the passable northern route.  “It is fair to charge a
label: BODY

text: property owner with knowledge of what happens on his land,” so long as those activities
label: BODY

text: are open and notorious.  See Catellus, 31 Fed. Cl. at 408; see also Entines v. United
label: BODY

text: States, 39 Fed. Cl. 673, 680 (1997) (“It is important to remember that tolling is not
label: BODY

text: appropriate for claims that are simply burdensome or inconvenient to discover.”).  As
label: BODY

text: the trial court correctly observed in this case, “A property owner is charged with
label: BODY

text: knowledge of what happens on his property even if the land is remote and difficult to
label: BODY

text: access.”  81 Fed. Cl. at 667.  Because we agree with the trial court that Mr. Ingrum’s
label: BODY

text: claim was not inherently unknowable when the alleged taking occurred in April 1999, we
label: BODY

text: uphold the court’s decision dismissing his claim as time-barred.
label: BODY

text: AFFIRMED.
label: BODY
